awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate questions related to the variational theory of minimal surfaces and its applications.  Minimal surfaces, of which soap bubbles are an illustrative example, are among the most natural objects in differential geometry.  They have applications in many areas, such as three-dimensional topology, mathematical physics, complex and conformal geometry, and materials science.  In general relativity, minimal surfaces appear as models for the apparent horizons of black holes.  The minimal surface equation plays a very important role as a model for several kinds of nonlinear phenomena.  Minimal surfaces have also been recently used in the design of materials  with applications in biology and in chemistry. The project also includes training of PhD students and junior researchers.  The PI will also disseminate his work through lectures, conferences, and workshops.

This project will advance our basic understanding of minimal surfaces and their general existence theory.  It concerns foundational questions about when these objects exist and how their properties relate to features of the ambient.  The aim is to investigate the  Morse-theoretic properties of the space of minimal varieties in a given Riemannian manifold. The idea is to use a combination of min-max methods, with the Almgren-Pitts min-max theory, and topological methods with the existence of homotopically nontrivial families of varieties. PI will study several questions related to this theme, including constructions of minimal hypersurfaces in higher dimensions and in the noncompact case. The project also includes plans for continued training of PhD students and post-doctoral researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The project has supported research of the PI and of graduate  students at Princeton University. The main topic is the existence theory of closed minimal surfaces. Minimal surfaces are central objects in Differential Geometry. Their defining equation also appears in physics, biology, architecture and other applied domains. These surfaces are in equilibrium with respect to forces that tend to minimize the surface area.  We have explored new directions which connect to some classic results on closed geodesics and on Laplace eigenfunctions.  The purpose of the research supported by this grant is to consider these objects in more general spaces, more specifically non-Euclidean geometries which could be curved (Riemann spaces).  The most appealing question is to look for closed surfaces, which close up in themselves like the surface of a sphere or of a torus. We found new relations between the minimal surface entropy, an invariant devised to count incompressible area-minimizing surfaces in compact hyperbolic three-dimensional manifolds, and the Liouville entropy of the geodesic flow in negatively curved spaces.  In positive curvature we constructed new geometries which admit continuous families of minimal surfaces spanning any tangent space. This generalizes the notion of Zoll surface for which  geodesics are closed. We investigated the inverse problem of characterizing the geometry of a space by its volume spectrum. This is a sequence of invariants defined using   the area functional  in analogy with the sequence of Laplace eigenvalues. We proved that the constant curvature projective plane is determined modulo isometries, in the class of compact Riemannian manifolds, by its volume spectrum. This space is the first example with this rigidity property. This project was fundamental to support the scientific activities of our group and  helped training graduate students who will become educators.  The research produced with the support of this project gives some important contributions to the discipline of differential geometry with emphasis on developing variational  applications for  the area.


Last Modified: 12/04/2024
Modified by: Fernando C Marques
